abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings assess the project as
            satisfactory, sustainability as likely, and institutional
            development impacts as substantial. Lessons address the
            importance of continuity in project leadership, and staff,
            for although the project suffered during preparation, and
            implementation due to the constant changes of the Director
            of the Tax Department, the continuity of top officials in
            the General Directorate of Taxes (GDT), benefited project
            outcomes. In addition, partly due to the lack of support by
            the Ministry of Finance, the work of the Project
            Implementation Unit could have been seriously hampered, had
            it not been for its valuable professional staff, who were
            able to assist GDT implement the last phase of the project,
            including international competitive bidding, under severe
            constraints. This leads to GDT management levels, where
            priorities should be carefully managed, so as to ensure
            that, given the limited human, and financial resources, the
            most important activities are implemented. Nonetheless, the
            project scope rightly focused on the implementation of the
            new functional organization, and on procedures for a single
            tax - the Value Added Tax (VAT) - to prod the success of GDT
            by limiting the objectives, but retaining its capacity as
            the new tax administrator, and, certainly the Bank's
            approval on the use of cost savings to expand VAT systems,
            allowed GDT to test its own (successful) managerial
            capacity. However, incentives to retain qualified personnel,
            be it training, or enhanced challenging work, remain essential.
